dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObjects.title: Taxonomy
dataObjects.description: It can be distinguished from other species of the fighting fish coccina group by its unique reddish body colour pattern with, among other characteristics, a large lateral dark green/blue blotch in males and females.Members of the coccina group form a natural assemblage - a group of organisms that includes all descendants of a common ancestor - that is endemic to the peat swamp forests of south east Asia.Current research at the Museum is exploring the fish’s evolutionary history and looking at the historical and ecological factors that may have shaped its distribution.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObjects.title: Introduction
dataObjects.description: Betta brownorum (Witte and Schmidt, 1992) is a representative of the species-group coccina, which includes a total of 9 miniature species of fighting fish.Like several other species of fighting fishes, the males are intensively coloured compared to the females. Male Betta brownorum are very aggressive to each other.The species are distributed mostly in non-overlapping locations in south east Asia - Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo and Sumatra.Betta brownorum occurs only in an extreme environment - the peat swamp forests of Sarawak, the Malaysian part of Borneo. Here the waters are tea-coloured and highly acidic (pH<4) but low in nutrients and dissolved oxygen.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Biology
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Betta brownorum lives in very shallow water bodies where complex root systems and high concentration of dead vegetation provide natural protection against predators.Its diet is mainly composed of arthropods.During the breeding season, the male builds up a nest formed by bubble aggregation using air and saliva - a bubble-nest. He then provides protection to the nest, and takes care of the fertilised eggs and early larval stages.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Inhabit very shallow waters in peat swamp forests.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology
dataObjects.title: Distribution ecology
dataObjects.description:
Tropical peat swamp forests (PSFs), are waterlogged forests growing on a layer of dead plant material up to 20 metres thick. They are one of the most threatened ecosystems in the world.More than 60% of the world’s tropical PSFs are found in south east Asia. PSFs comprise an ancient and unique ecosystem characterised by low nutrients and highly acidic black water - down to pH3.They provide crucial ecosystem services, including:
  • control of water storage
  • coastal erosion prevention
  • flood mitigation
  • future atmospheric carbon sequestration

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Conservation
dataObjects.title: Conservation
dataObjects.description: It is difficult to obtain precise information on the distribution and abundance of fish species and the conservation status of Betta brownorum is not listed as of particular concern by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).However, peat swamp forests in Sarawak are being rapidly destroyed and converted into oil palm plantations.This raises concerns about the future of this species and other endemic peat swamp forest fish.
